definition: unheard of/an extremely rare and unprecedented event
actually/place/classifier for houses, small buildings, institutions etc/that which/particle introducing a relative clause or passive/CL:個|个[ge4]
not yet/did not/have not/not/8th earthly branch: 1-3 p.m., 6th solar month (7th July-6th August), year of the Sheep/ancient Chinese compass point: 210°

sentences.english: There was more  name-calling in the campaign for senator than I ever heard before.
sentences.chinese: 在那次参议员竞选中相互谩骂之多是我闻所未闻的。

sentences.english: That would hardly be unheard of.
There is something unheard of in medical history abroad.
sentences.chinese: 这是在国外医学史上闻所未闻的事。

sentences.english: There was more name-calling in the campaign for senator than I ever heard before.
sentences.chinese: 在那次参议员竞选中相互谩骂之多是我闻所未闻的。

sentences.english: She had heard of a poisonous dart sewn into a bodice to pierce the flesh, but she had never heard of anyone being killed by embroidery before.
sentences.chinese: 她虽听说过绵里藏针，但用刺绣杀人却是闻所未闻。

sentences.english: They will tell you many things which you have never known and whereat you will be amazed.
sentences.chinese: 他们会告诉你许多你闻所未闻，使你拍案称奇的事情。

sentences.english: Hughan said such incidents were rare but not unheard of.
sentences.chinese: 胡根表示，类似事件尽管罕见，但也并非闻所未闻。

sentences.english: Such acquittals are unusual but not unheard of in China.
sentences.chinese: 这样的无罪判决在中国不常见，但也并非闻所未闻。

definition: to click one's tongue in wonder (idiom)/to be astonished
(idiom) to gasp in amazement/to acclaim as the peak of perfection
tongue-tied/unable to speak (out of surprise, embarrassment etc)
